meta.title: SVG Background: 5 Mistakes to Avoid and a Few Useful Pointers

meta.name: description
meta.content: Create the perfect background SVG designs for any project, and build on top of their unmatched web and mobile performance by following these easy tips!
SVG Background: 5 Mistakes to Avoid and a Few Useful Pointers
Want to use an SVG background as a moodsetter for your design projects? See what common slip-ups can take away from the end result, and how you can bypass them easily!

meta.content: SVG Background: 5 Mistakes to Avoid and a Few Useful Pointers

meta.content: Want to use an SVG background as a moodsetter for your design projects? See what common slip-ups can take away from the end result, and how you can bypass them easily!

meta.name: robots

img.alt: SVGator Blog
SVG Background: 5 Mistakes to Avoid and a Few Useful Pointers

div.h1: SVG Background: 5 Mistakes to Avoid and a Few Useful Pointers
div.p: Want to use an SVG background as a moodsetter for your design projects? See what common slip-ups can take away from the end result, and how you can bypass them easily!

If there‚Äôs one area of digital visual design that we‚Äôve seen evolve without much struggle, it‚Äôs certainly background design. Everyone seemed to get on the same page relatively quickly, particularly before high-speed internet services became globally accessible. An SVG background was the easiest switch to make to avoid using heavy slow-to-load background images.
SVG background graphics, created with free SVG creator tools like SVGator or generated using tools like Matt Visiwig‚Äôs SVGBackgrounds, make it effortless for designers to have a quick-to-load web and mobile-friendly background done in a matter of a few clicks.
As easy as it sounds, there are a few common mistakes that can cancel out the benefits of using an SVG background image. Let‚Äôs address these kinks and see what tactics you can implement to get it right each and every time!

object.alt: Example of a SVG animated background

img.alt: Example of a SVG animated background

div.p: As iconic (and nostalgic!) as 90s website backgrounds were, they were an outright pain to load, though a joy to see on CRT screens for the first time! We have to thank them for testing our patience, because we haven‚Äôt stopped looking for ways to make all things digital load faster ever since!

img.alt: SVG background inspired by the 90s space nostalgia
img.figcaption: Blast from the past: 90s inspired web design by CameronsWorld

div.p:
An SVG background image has the same features as any other scalable vector graphic, performance-wise. It is significantly smaller in size (compared to any of its raster counterparts), it is infinitely scalable, and it is fully-responsive. It will never lose sharpness or clarity no matter the screen size or resolution of the device it‚Äôs displayed on.
Using SVG as a background image is technically no different than using other formats (like PNG or JPG). The vector format simply has the incontestable upper hand when it comes to loading speed. A static fullscreen background SVG file can easily come under 5KB, and even an SVG background animation can have a file size as small as 8KB.

img.alt: Animated background with particles moving around

div.p: As with any other form of digital design, the SVG background isn‚Äôt exempt from following an (albeit permissive) rulebook. That‚Äôs not to say that there is a definite right or wrong way to go about creating background scalable vector graphics. But there are a few mistakes that might be holding you back from creating truly outstanding vector backgrounds.
Don‚Äôt worry; we‚Äôre not here to only point a finger! We‚Äôre also sharing some easy tips that you can carry over into your SVG background design workflow and never second guess yourself again!
div.h3: Limiting yourself to a static SVG background image
div.p:
Few things are easier, or quicker, to do than just settling on an SVG background color and moving on to more pressing design choices. Sure, you‚Äôll need to put more thought into what UI design style to pursue, or what type of iconography would make for a more intuitive user experience. But, in this case, you‚Äôre 100% selling yourself short of a way more enthralling design altogether.
Creating an animated SVG background that captures user attention has the same effect as setting the ambiance of an environment to match the ‚Äúevent.‚Äù Why have a candle-lit dinner in a neon-lit room, when you could be hanging up fairy lights and have a dimly lit view of the night skyline? By incorporating vector animation into the design process, you increase your ability to customize the user navigation journey tenfold.

object.alt: Animated Background with geometric shapes moving around

img.alt: Animated Background with geometric shapes moving around

p.br:
Create your own custom animated background SVG without writing a single line of code with an online SVG animation tool. Explore all the ways motion vector graphics can elevate your designs, from basic gradient background animations, to floating geometric shapes, neumorphic color drops, celestial particles, and everything else in between.
Once you‚Äôre comfortable with animating an SVG background that fits the mood you‚Äôre going for, you can move right to the next level: immersive interactive SVG backgrounds! With the help of no-code interactive SVG animation, you can have your backgrounds animate as they scroll into the viewport, and even include a captivating (and memorable!) parallax effect. No need to limit yourself to a static background when dynamic background animations are now easier to create more than ever before.

object.alt: Interactive SVG background that tells a story

img.alt: Interactive SVG background that tells a story

div.h3: Interfering with visual hierarchy and accessibility
div.p:
Entertainment and visual magnetism aside, an SVG background shouldn‚Äôt hinder your ability to establish a logical visual hierarchy, whether it be on a website‚Äôs landing page or in a mobile app‚Äôs UI. Visual hierarchy, by definition, dictates that the elements of a graphic design should be arranged in the order of their importance. The designer has the responsibility to direct the user‚Äôs attention and lighten the mental load of deciding what to focus on and in what order.
In sync with keeping the viewer‚Äôs eye in the right place, making sure that your background design follows the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines is a must. You wouldn‚Äôt want to put time and effort into a project only to realize you‚Äôre inadvertently limiting the size of the audience that can successfully, and comfortably, navigate your designs.

object.alt: Animated background with patterns changing shapes and moving around

img.alt: Animated background with patterns changing shapes and moving around

div.p: Take into account the Z-pattern and F-pattern principles of digital visual hierarchy. Make sure your SVG background doesn‚Äôt distract from or obscure any vital piece of content. What we, as designers see as perfectly distinguishable might look like a blur to some users. The best practices in this case are to run usability testing periodically, and stay up to date with accessibility criteria, particularly 1.4.3 Contrast (Minimum).

img.alt: Animated SVG background with geometric shapes changing focus

div.p:
While it is true that by default your SVG background is a lightweight competitor in the file size field, we are aiming for lightning-fast loading speed in this day and age. Every second shaved off that page load time puts us one step closer to offering a better user experience.
An animated background SVG, topped with a few cool animation effects, can run up the numbers easily and put a damper on your design‚Äôs otherwise optimal performance. For example, if you‚Äôre starting your background design SVG in a program like Illustrator, and then moving to SVGator to breathe life into the project, you can carry over quite a bit of ‚Äúbloat.‚Äù But luckily, there are ways to trim off the excess!

object.alt: Reduce the number of nodes in a SVG for better performance

img.alt: Reduce the number of nodes in a SVG for better performance

div.p: In the case of Illustrator imports, changes as small as using a simplified path to draw your background elements and avoiding setting your Pencil or Brush tools to Accurate can make a huge difference in how large the end-file turns out to be.

Follow the tips from our ‚ÄúOptimize SVG Animations to Improve Your Page Speed‚Äù blog post, and optimize your SVG background to get complex results like the example below with a featherlight file size of only 50KB!

object.alt: Animated SVG background with colorful textures moving around

img.alt: Animated SVG background with colorful textures moving around

div.h3: Not prototyping with your SVG background
div.p:
Considering the fact that the background SVG you choose will set the undertones of your entire project, this mistake might cost you loads in terms of consistent design. Much like a painter giving their canvas a paint wash and later using that base layer to create highlights and shadows, so does prototyping with an animated background SVG make it easier for you to later decide on ideal spacing, alignment, use of negative space, contrast, etc.
Treating your SVG background image as an afterthought might save you time in the short term, but more often than not, you‚Äôll later find yourself either compromising with an ultra-basic SVG background color or unnecessarily lengthening the iterative process.
Key pointers
Use a prototyping tool like Figma, Penpot, or Protopie to conceptualize your design process starting with the background design SVG. Instead of hitting that first creative block when staring at a stark white drawing board, you can build on top of an already contoured backdrop.
While some prototyping tools don‚Äôt support animated SVG at the moment, there are workarounds that can help you through the process, like using a GIF of the same design as a placeholder. You can also preview your design using website builders, like Squarespace, Wix or Webflow. Whatever tool you end up using, your visual storytelling will unfold much more smoothly with a background SVG in place.

object.alt: Animated SVG files are supported on all types of devices

img.alt: Animated SVG files are supported on all types of devices

div.h3: Not using your background SVG to its fullest potential
div.p: Let‚Äôs look at this fault objectively, and see what default advantages come with using SVG backgrounds:

- Small file size (even for an animated SVG background)? ‚òëÔ∏èCheck.
- Addressed visual hierarchy and accessibility concerns? ‚òëÔ∏èCheck.
- Optimal performance thanks to quick load times? ‚òëÔ∏èCheck.
- Makes for a cohesive iteration process from the very beginning? ‚òëÔ∏èCheck.
So, what else can a background SVG bring to the table?
You can make your animated SVG background as plain or as intricate as you‚Äôd like without having to worry about adding extra seconds to a page or mobile app‚Äôs loading time.
It is so versatile! You can make it part of your branding efforts, use it to hop on user interface design trends, make a landing page‚Äôs above-the-fold section look like an immersive portal ‚Äì and do all this with responsive design in tow by default!

We‚Äôve gathered a small collection of awesome animated SVG backgrounds to get the creative ball rolling:
Cute Animated Pattern - By Margarita Ivanchikova
Animated background SVG patterns don‚Äôt need uniform repetition to work as intended. Subtle animation effects on geometric flat art, even with varying easing, make for a very cute pattern.

img.alt: Cute animated background made by Margarita Ivanchikova

br.br:
Circles Rolling in Colors - By ILLO
With SVG optimization, an intensely catchy and memorable animated SVG background like this can be very quick to load. Maximum engagement potential, without any (page) speed bumps in the way!

img.alt: Animated background with circles rolling in colors made by ILLO

p.br:
Tile Animated Pattern - By Domaso
A tile-based animated SVG background that makes us think of the back-in-trend Bauhaus-style ‚Äì complete with ultra-smooth transitions and room to customize with any brand‚Äôs colors.

img.alt: Animated background with a tile pattern made by Domaso

p.br:
Geometric City - ILLO
Giving dimension to apparently flat elements is how illustrator Cristina Pasquale and animator Dave Cubitt describe this high-energy animation. A perfect example of setting the tone of a page even before a single headline is written!

img.alt: Animated background with gemotric shapes forming a city made by ILLO

p.br:
Geometric Animation - By Aleksei Vasileika
Isometric elements in an animated SVG background will never not be impressive! You can create them with isometric geometric shapes and get stunning results.

Connection - By ILLO
Want to use an SVG background to jump on graphic design trends? Nothing easier! Animated self-drawing thin lines can make any background feel exhilarating and set the mood for some very upbeat content.

img.alt: Animated background with moving lines made by ILLO

div.p:
Animated Particle Effect - By SVGator
Using only four paths, we created this animated SVG background with a particle bokeh-ish effect with a petite file size of only 8KB. Made from start to finish in SVGator‚Äôs intuitive interface!

iframe.style: background: white; max-width: 540px; width: calc(100% - 2px); border-radius: 3px; border: 1px solid rgb(219, 219, 219); box-shadow: none; display: block; margin: 0px 0px 12px; min-width: 326px; padding: 0px;

p.br:
Shooting Star - By Yusuke Nakaya
Shooting for the stars with your next design project? Put the light show directly into your SVG background!

div.iframe: See the Pen astronaut-150 speed 12 fps V4 by Yusuke Nakaya (Yusuke Nakaya) on CodePen.

p.br:
Ambient Background - By Dimitra Vasilopoulou
Nothing says ‚Äúcome in and stay a while‚Äù like a chill animated ambient background. Just the right message you‚Äôd want to convey to a website visitor!

div.iframe: See the Pen astronaut-150 speed 12 fps V4 by Yusuke Nakaya (Dimitra Vasilopoulou) on CodePen.
div.p:
Infinite SVG Triangle Fusion - By Rob DiMarzo
We couldn‚Äôt look away from this hypnotic SVG background! Precisely the energy you‚Äôre looking for when adding elements of interest to your design project.
div.iframe: See the Pen astronaut-150 speed 12 fps V4 by Yusuke Nakaya (Rob DiMarzo) on CodePen.
div.p: There's a lot more to an SVG background than its small file size and ease of loading; you can take yours to entirely new heights with just a few tweaks that will ultimately elevate your entire design project. Want to try your hand at drawing and animating your best background SVG yet? Hop onto your SVGator account here and make it happen!
